SATURDAY
ON 48 HOURSHere's a note 
      from Troy Roberts on Saturday's 48 Hours Mystery, POWER, 
      PASSION AND POISON: "Kathy Augustine was a 
      rising star in Nevada state politics. Smart, ambitious, tough and 
      attractive she quickly ascended to one of the highest offices in the state 
      and many expected she'd eventually end up working in national politics. 
      But last year Kathy Augustine was found unconscious in her bed and later 
      died at the hospital. She was fifty-years-old. At first it was assumed 
      that Augustine died from a heart attack. But her family and friends didn't 
      believe it could be possible. Augustine had her annual physical just a 
      week before her death. She was given a clean bill of health and there was 
      no family history of heart disease. It just didn't add up. 
      Toxicology tests were ordered on fluid samples taken from 
      Augustine and the results shocked everyone. Traces of the powerful 
      paralytic drug Succinylcholine were found in her system. The drug is 
      normally given to patients to ease the insertion of a breathing tube. It 
      acts fast and nearly vanishes from the body within minutes...making it 
      extremely difficult to detect. Suspicions quickly fell on Augustine's 
      husband of three years, Chazz Higgs. The pair seemed an unlikely couple. 
      He was eight-years her junior. He was a bodybuilder who had three failed 
      marriages behind him. His relationship with Kathy was troubled as well. In 
      the months leading up to Augustine's death they had discussed divorce. But 
      there was more. Chaz Higgs was a critical care nurse and he had access to 
      Succincolyine. He knew how to adminster it and, most importantly, he knew 
      the drug could be potentially deadly. And then a witness came forward with 
      a damning claim about his allegedly role in the crime. Chazz Higgs 
      goes on trial for the murder of Kathy Augustine next month. Higgs claims 
      he is innocent. When we sat down for the interview, that you'll see this 
      weekend, he agreed to talk about the charges against him...charges that 
      could send him to prison for life, and you'll hear his theories on who 
      would want his wife dead...and why. I hope you'll join us on Saturday 
      night." - Troy Roberts (48 Hours Mystery 
      airs Saturday at 10pmET/9CT) If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us at: 48hours@cbsnews.com 
      



TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING NEWSHere's an early look at what we are working on for 
      tonight's broadcast of the CBS Evening News, from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric.. Hi everyone, Today a 
      Defense Department panel warned that more than one-third of U.S. troops 
      and veterans suffer from mental health problems such as traumatic brain 
      injury or post-traumatic stress disorder. With the conflicts in Iraq and 
      Afghanistan continuing, these numbers are only expected to grow, according 
      to the group. David Martin will have this story and a deeper look 
      at veterans mental health issues. Correspondent Allen 
      Pizzey will introduce you to an Army specialist with a special 
      perseverance  and a unique perspective on the roadside attacks that 
      injure so many American troops: Specialist Jordan Spurlin has survived 
      four IED explosions. Now hes sharing his story. A boat carrying 
      an estimated 150 Haitian migrants capsized in the Atlantic Ocean this 
      morning. Kelly Cobiella will have the latest on the Coast Guards 
      frantic search for survivors. Ten presidential hopefuls lined up 
      on stage last night, but what memorable about it? Our senior political 
      correspondent Jeff Greenfield will have a review of the first 
      Republican debate. Queen Elizabeth II is causing quite a stir at 
      the site of one of Americas first colonies. Mark Phillips will 
      follow her through Jamestown  where Brits settled 400 years ago  and 
      take a look back through its history and how it is recently being revised. 
      A bit of trivia: Who is the only sitting U.S. senator to serve on 
      active duty in Iraq? Sharyl Attkisson will have that exclusive 
      story tonight, and shell explain the work this lawmaker has done recently 
      for the military. Finally, for Assignment 
      America Steve Hartman will have a sweet 
      story about a small-town family fighting to save their roots  one 
      hand-dipped chocolate at a time. I hope you join us tonight and 
      have a great weekend!
 
Katie

TOMORROW ON THE SATURDAY EARLY SHOWTracy 
      Smith and Chris Wragge of our New York affiliate, WCBS, 
      anchor THE SATURDAY EARLY SHOW from New York. Ira Joe 
      Fisher will bring us the weather. Along with the top news 
      of the day, we will also have the following stories: HAPPINESS 
      MYTH: Can a person achieve true happiness? Not the traditional way is 
      Jennifer Michael Hechts answer, author of The Happiness Myth: Why What 
      We Think Is Right Is Wrong. In her new book, she asks her readers to 
      rethink the modern methods of pursuing happiness  through money, our 
      bodies, celebrations, and drugs. Using historical examples, Hecht aims to 
      prove that individuals can achieve their own happiness when they snap out 
      of a cultural trance and move beyond the societal constructs within 
      which we live our lives. She will join us with her unique perspective 
      Saturday morning. REPAIR OR REPLACE?: Electronics are 
      expensive investments, but sometimes it might be best to just replace it 
      than try to repair it. To show us the difference, AOL consumer adviser 
      Regina Lewis will offers tips on how to decide whether to fix that broken 
      PC, BlackBerry, cell phone, or iPod  or just buy a new one. 
      BIG-SCREEN ROMANCES: Saturday morning, we will preview this 
      summers best on-screen romances from Peter (Spidey) Parker & Mary 
      Jane in Spiderman 3 to the timeless romance of Homer and Marge 
      Simpson in The Simpsons Movie. David Edelstein of New York 
      magazine and Jill Bernstein of Entertainment Weekly will join us 
      with what hopeless romantics can look forward to this summer. 
      QUEEN AT DERBY: Queen Elizabeth II, one of the worlds 
      best-known fans of horses and horse racing, will attend her first Kentucky 
      Derby and associated festivities on Saturday. CBS News Correspondent 
      Mark Phillips has been following the queens visit to the U.S. and 
      will bring us the latest on her activities from Louisville, KY. 
      BICYCLES: Biking enthusiasts can rejoice with spring 
      finally here. But is your bike on its last wheel? We will turn to 
      Bicycling magazine Editor-in-Chief Steve Madden for all we need to 
      know about buying a bicycle. He will show us some of the cool new features 
      on todays bikes. He will also offer upgrade suggestions for those who 
      just cant seem to part with their old trusty. CHEF ON A 
      SHOESTRING: Saturday is Cinco de Mayo and were celebrating! Hot 
      Boston chef Ken Oringer has recently opened a Mexican restaurant called La 
      Verdad. He will join us with his Mexican-inspired dishes to help get your 
      holiday off to a spicy start all on our $40 budget. SECOND CUP 
      CAFE: Carly Simon, a 70s singer-songwriter well-known for hits like 
      Youre so Vain, hasnt stopped her musical ambitions. The two-time 
      Grammy winner recently released Into White, an album that covers 
      classic songs by esteemed artists like Judy Garland and the Beatles. It 
      also features vocals by her children Ben and Sally Taylor. Simon will 
      perform songs from her latest album with her gifted daughter Sally in our 
      Second Cup Café. To look for our fabulous recipes... Click 
      Here If you would like more information on any of these 
      stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail 
      us: sat@cbsnews.com 


HERE'S WHAT WE HAVE PLANNED FOR SUNDAY 
      MORNINGCHARLES OSGOOD ANCHORS FROM NEW YORK 
      WHAT'S FOR BREAKFAST?: Cereal still rules at the American 
      breakfast table, but the trend is toward dashboard dining and cup-holder 
      cuisine. Cynthia Bowers looks at how America eats the most 
      important meal of the day - in our Sunday Morning cover 
      story. SUNDAY ALMANAC: We'll look back to this day, May 6, 
      1937 when the airship Hindenburg crashed and burned in Lakewood, NJ. 
      EMAIL ETIQUETTE: Technology Correspondent Daniel 
      Sieberg has pointers on proper on-line etiquette. SUMMER 
      MOVIES: We'll get a sneak preview of some of the films that will be 
      coming to a theater near you this summer. Jerry Bowen tells us 
      which ones could bring in big bucks at the box office. TONY 
      SNOW: Correspondent Rita Braver talks with White House Press 
      Secretary Tony Snow about his battle with cancer and returning to his 
      position as the President's spokesman. MUSIC - ASLEEP AT THE 
      WHEEL: With his band Asleep at the Wheel, Ray Benson loves makin' 
      music with his friends. A booming baritone, Benson likes to say he's 
      reinventing the wheel - the title of their new CD. Asleep at the Wheel, a 
      western swing band from Austin, Texas, started rolling in 1970 and never 
      stopped. We'll ride along with them this Sunday Morning. 
      THE OUTER LIMITS: Throughout their lives the baby boomers 
      have done things their own way. And the same philosophy seems to apply to 
      how they intend to go into the great beyond. Instead of a traditional 
      burial, more and more people are opting for cremation these days. And 
      there are more and more ways to turn those ashes into memorials to the 
      departed. They can be scattered at sea, or made into jewelry, sporting 
      equipment, artificial reefs, or even fireworks. One of the most dramatic 
      tributes is to shoot them into space. Last weekend, Bill Geist 
      traveled to New Mexico where a private rocket launched so-called 
      "cremains" of 202 people into space. Onboard were some of the ashes of 
      pioneering astronaut Zombie Cooper and James Doohan-"Scotty" from Star 
      Trek. We'll meet the families of some of those on-board, and learn 
      more about how the baby boomers are redefining even death. If you 
      would like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, 
      please click on the following address and e-mail us: sundays@cbsnews.com 


SUNDAY ON FACE THE 
      NATION Bob Schieffer moderates...Sunday on Face the 
      Nation, the subjects will be war and politics and the guests: For 
      the Republicans, former House Speaker Newt Gingrich who says he may throw 
      his hat into the Presidential ring this fall. For the Democrats: Chairman 
      of the House Ways and Means Committee, Charlie Rangel of New York. We'll 
      talk to both about the war, politics, the agenda of the parties and more. 
      There will be, as always, a final word. That's all on Face the 
      Nation, this Sunday, with Bob Schieffer. 


SUNDAY ON 60 MINUTESINSIDE THE ENEMY 
      CAMP: Until Osama bin Laden declared all Americans and Jews fair 
      targets for al Qaeda terror, Nazir Abas trained Muslim militants in the 
      jungles of Southeast Asia. Now he provides valuable intelligence to 
      authorities in the war on terror. Bob Simon reports. LOU 
      DOBBS: Lesley Stahl profiles the CNN anchor, whose stance against 
      illegal immigration has helped raise his ratings but also fueled 
      criticism. THRIFT SHOP MASTERPIECE?: Teri Horton knew 
      nothing about art when she bought a big, drippy painting for five dollars 
      years ago in a thrift store. But now she says a fingerprint proves it is a 
      $50 million Jackson Pollock original. Anderson Cooper reports. 
      



MONDAY MORNING ON THE 
      EARLY SHOWHarry Smith, Hannah 
      Storm, Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor THE 
      EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave Price will bring us the 
      weather. Along with the top news of the day, we will also have 
      the following stories: WITHOUT A TRACE: What happened 
      to Khoi Vu? Khoi Vu was last seen by his family sometime between the hours 
      of midnight and 1 a.m. on the morning of April 7, 2007, at the home which 
      he shares with his family in Clark County, Washington. On Sundays 
      Without A Trace, Khoi Vu was revealed as this weeks missing 
      person. Find out the story behind his bizarre disappearance and see if you 
      can help solve this mystery. CSI WEEK: A VISIT TO THE SET OF 
      CSI MIAMI: Monday morning we kick off CSI week with a look at 
      the most popular show in the world. It may be called CSI Miami, but 
      thanks to Hollywood magic the show normally shoots in California. Several 
      times a year they go on location to it's namesake city. That's where 
      EARLY SHOW National Correspondent Tracy Smith caught 
      up with the show's cast. Monday morning, shell take us on a tour of the 
      red hot show. PITFALLS OF MEDICAL SCREENING: Traditionally 
      it has been your doctor who has decided if you need to have a medical test 
      done. But now a growing number of people are paying to have medical 
      screenings done without the approval of their doctors. Our Dr. Emily 
      Senay will join us to explain. PERFECT PARENTING: FINDING A 
      NANNY: The days of your neighborhood babysitter are long gone and 
      finding a more permanent caretaker for your child can be a daunting task. 
      What should you look for when you search for a nanny? Well have tips that 
      can help you avoid a nanny nightmare and make sure that your child will be 
      in good hands. SHRINK YOURSELF: THE BEST YOU CAN BE: For 
      many people food offers a time out from life's stresses and 
      disappointments. A delicious bowl of ice cream can make a bad day seem 
      better. Psychiatrist Roger Gould writes about freeing yourself from 
      emotional eating in his new book, Shrink Yourself. He will join us 
      Monday morning with some ways to begin a healthier relationship with food. 
      BRYCE DALLAS HOWARD ON SPIDERMAN 3: It's been a pretty good 
      year for actress Bryce Dallas Howard. Last summer, she got married and in 
      February Howard gave birth to son Theo. Now, she gets to celebrate the big 
      opening of the blockbuster Spiderman 3, in which plays the new 
      character Gwen Stacy. Monday morning Bryce will join us to give us the 
      inside scoop on what is was like to be a part of the Spiderman 
      phenomenon. AMAZING RACE: ALL STARS WINNING TEAM!: On 
      Sunday nights season finale of the Amazing Race: All Stars, Dustin 
      and Kandice have a disagreement and Charla and Mirna rely on their wit in 
      order to beat the physically stronger teams. Who will walk away with a 
      first place finish? Monday morning, the final two teams will join us live 
      on our plaza where we will present the winning team with their million 
      dollar check! If you would like more information on any of these 
      stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and e-mail 
      us: earlyshow@cbs.com
